docs.title: Welcome to the JellyFAAS docs
docs.text: Integrate seamlessly into your work flow.

docs.title: Behind the scenes
docs.text:
Your function calls do a lot behind the scenes that you don't see!

sequenceDiagram
Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Authourise Api key
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: JWT

Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Lookup function
JellyFaas Api->>+JellyFaas Functions Library: Lookup function 
JellyFaas Functions Library->>-JellyFaas Api: Function requirments and dns 
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: Function requirments and dns 

Client->>+JellyFaas Api: Invoke
JellyFaas Api->>+JellyFaas Cloud Instance: Invoke
    critical Connect to function instance
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: connect
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: run
        JellyFaas Cloud Instance-->Google Cloud Function: process response 
    end
JellyFaas Cloud Instance->>-JellyFaas Api: Function response
JellyFaas Api->>-Client: Function response

docs.title: Getting Started Guide
docs.text: We've stream lined everything, so you don't have too.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
We support a wide range of languages - find your language to get started with our SDK.

PythonJavaGoC#Node

The JellyFaaS SDK Python package is available on PyPI. Source code can be viewed on GitHub. 

pip install jellyfaas

Add this dependency to your POM.xml file if you are using maven. 

<dependency>
    // placeholder
</dependency>

Source code can be viewed on GitHub.

Install the SDK via 

go get github.com/Platform48/go_sdk
Then add it to your projects go.mod file with 
go mod tidy

Source code can be viewed on GitHub.

Source code can be viewed on GitHub.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK simplifies working with the JellyFaaS API. It primarily provides a Client class which handles authentication and functions to simplify creating HTTP requests to the API.

API Credits

The cloud functions used in the examples below will not use your credits. Click here to get an api key.

Below are some quick start examples you can plug and play into.

PythonJavaGoC#Node

main.py

from jellyfaas import Client, ClientConfig

# Initialize the client config
config = ClientConfig("<JELLYFAAS_API_KEY>")

# 1. Create Client, 2. lookup JellyFaaS function, 3. pass in query params and body, 4. invoke!
client, response = Client(config).lookup_function("helloworld")
                                 .set_request({"name": "tim"}, {"order": ["ham", "jam", "spam"]})
                                 .invoke()

print(response)
# Output: "Hello, Tim. You ordered 'ham', 'jam', and 'spam'."

More Info - Verbose Example

The above code example demonstrates how the entire JellyFaaS function calling workflow can be condensed down into a succinct one-liner. Of course, you may prefer a more a clear and verbose approach. The following code example demonstrates how you can improve code-clarity by expanding out this process. 

import os
import logging
import jellyfaas

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG) # When enabled, JellyFaaS logs at the DEBUG level

# It is usually recommended to set up your API key as an environment variable.
api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

# Initialize the client config with debug logs enabled
config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)

# Initialize the client
client = jellyfaas.Client(config)

# Lookup a function
client.lookup_function("helloworld")

# Set the request query params and JSON body (via a python dictionary)
client.set_request(
    {"name": "tim"},                # Set query parameters
    {"order": ["ham", "jam", "spam"]}) # Set request body

# Finally, call the cloud function
_, response = client.invoke()

print(response)
# Output: "Hello, Tim. You ordered 'ham', 'jam', and 'spam'."

Warning

You must add the respective input and output classes provided on the website, if there are any, in order to process JSON requests and responses. These are listed below in the example.

CodeInput ClassOutput Class

Main.java

package main;

import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonProcessingException;
import testSchemas.IbanOutputTest;
import testSchemas.IbanTest;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasException;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasFormatException;
import v1.jellyfaas.exceptions.JellyFaasHttpException;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws JellyFaasException, JellyFaasHttpException, IllegalAccessException, JsonProcessingException, JellyFaasFormatException {
        // setting the config object
        String apiKey = System.getenv("API_KEY");
        Config config = new Config();
        config.setApiKey(apiKey);

        //creating the client object
        Client client = new Client(config);
        IbanTest ibanTest = new IbanTest();
        ibanTest.addIban("FR1420041010050500013M02606");

        // invoking the object and putting the output into a new object
        IbanOutputTest output = (IbanOutputTest) client.lookUp("ibanvalidation").setRequest(null, ibanTest).setResponse(IbanOutputTest.class).invoke();
    }
}

Input.java

package main;

import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonProperty;
import v1.jellyfaas.JellyFaasFunctionSchema;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class IbanTest extends JellyFaasFunctionSchema {
    private List<String> ibans;

    public IbanTest(){
        this.ibans = new ArrayList<>();
    }

    public List<String> getIbans() {
        return this.ibans;
    }

    public void setIbans(List<String> ibans) {
        this.ibans = ibans;
    }

    public void addIban(String iban){
        this.ibans.add(iban);
    }
}

Output.java

package main;
import v1.jellyfaas.JellyFaasFunctionSchema;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class IbanOutputTest extends JellyFaasFunctionSchema {
    private String spanId;
    private Data data;

    // Getter and Setter for spanId
    public String getSpanId() {
        return spanId;
    }

    public void setSpanId(String spanId) {
        this.spanId = spanId;
    }

    // Getter and Setter for Data
    public Data getData() {
        return data;
    }

    public void setData(Data data) {
        this.data = data;
    }

    // Inner class Data
    public static class Data {
        private List<String> valid = new ArrayList<>();
        private List<String> invalid = new ArrayList<>();
        private int validCount = 0;
        private int invalidCount = 0;
        private int total = 0;

        // Getters and Setters for valid
        public List<String> getValid() {
            return valid;
        }

        public void setValid(List<String> valid) {
            this.valid = valid;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for invalid
        public List<String> getInvalid() {
            return invalid;
        }

        public void setInvalid(List<String> invalid) {
            this.invalid = invalid;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for validCount
        public int getValidCount() {
            return validCount;
        }

        public void setValidCount(int validCount) {
            this.validCount = validCount;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for invalidCount
        public int getInvalidCount() {
            return invalidCount;
        }

        public void setInvalidCount(int invalidCount) {
            this.invalidCount = invalidCount;
        }

        // Getters and Setters for total
        public int getTotal() {
            return total;
        }

        public void setTotal(int total) {
            this.total = total;
        }
    }
}

main.go

main.cs

main.js

Next Steps

  • Get started with the SDKS
  • Create your first function
  • Get started with our cli tool
  • Get your API key

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK simplifies working with the JellyFaaS API. It provides a Client class which handles authentication and functions to simplify creating HTTP requests to the API. It also provides additional validation and checks of your requests, to prevent making invalid function calls, which would otherwise consume API credits.

API Credits

The cloud functions used in the examples below will not use your credits. Click here to get an api key.

docs.title: In-depth start guides
docs.text:
If you are new to JellyFaaS or new to coding in general, we have some good start guides to get you going!

  • Java
  • Python
  • Golang
  • C#
  • Node

Next Steps

  • Create your first function
  • Get started with our cli tool
  • Get your API key

docs.title: Calling your first function (for noobs!)
docs.text: Now that you've added your POM dependency, you are ready to make your first call! Here's a step-by-step guide of how to do so. If you are new to the platform, or have limited coding experience, this walk-through is for you!

docs.title: 1. Creating a Config Object
docs.text:
The first step is to create your config object and parse your JellyFaaS api key into it:

// creating a config object
Config config = new Config();
config.setApiKey("API-KEY");

docs.title: 2. Creating the client
docs.text:
Once you've created your config object, you can create a client and parse this object in on instantiation: 

// setting the client
Client client = new Client(config);

docs.title: 3. Looking up a function
docs.text:
To look up a function, you must use the functions short name to find it. This is done with the following, provided all the previous steps are complete

// ...
// using the client created above

client.lookUp("shortname")

Looking up a function will influence the following steps as this sets the function to be called

docs.title: 4. Setting the request
docs.text:
Once you've called lookup on your client object, you can now set your request. If a function takes no query parameters and/or no input body, the setRequest parameters can be null respectively. This is done with the following:

client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody)

Note

params and inputBody are placeholders for the following steps

docs.title: 4.1 Adding Query Parameters
docs.text:
Creating query parameters is done by creating a Map<String, String> - where the key value pairs are the query parameter name and its value respectively.

Map<String, String> params = new HashMap<>();
params.put("queryParam", "foobar");

docs.title: 4.2 Adding a request body
docs.text:
If the request body is a JSON object, our website provides the auto generated code for the input and output classes for these json objects. You must copy and paste these classes and add them to your project as these are used to handle the input and output json responses for a given function.

Using an ObjectUsing a byte[]

Using the function's autogenerated input class from the website 

// creating an input object
SomeInputClass inputBody = new SomeInputClass();
someInput.setSomeAttribute("foobar");

If the function you are invoking does not have an auto generated class for the input body, then a byte[] must be used as the input body.

byte[] inputBody = "Hello, world!".getBytes();

docs.title: 5. Setting the response
docs.text:
There are three main ways to configure the output of a function invoke: Using an instance of the auto generated output class, using the class of the auto generated class, or using a byte[] to capture the output.

5.1 Using an instance5.2 Using a .class5.3 Using a byte[]

As mentioned previously, our website contains the auto generated Input/Output classes. Again, you must copy and paste these classes and add them to your project as these are used to handle the input and output json responses for a given function.

// creating an output object
SomeOutputClass someOutput = new SomeOutputClass();

Using this instance, setting the response is done with the following - provided all the above steps are completed: 

client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody).setResponse(someOutput);
This will use the instance and populate it once the function is invoked.

This approach can be used if you don't have an instance of the output object. Don't worry, when you invoke the function, a new object will be created using this type. 

client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody).setResponse(someOutput.class);

If a function doesn't return a json response, then a byte[].class must be used like in step 5.2: 

client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody).setResponse(byte[].class);

docs.title: 6. Calling the function 🚀
docs.text:
Now that you have done all the previous steps, you are ready to call your function. This is super easy! Just call .invoke() on your client and your function will be called with your request and response data!

6.1 Invoking with an output instance6.2 Invoking with a .class6.3 Invoking with a byte[]

If you followed step 5.1, then your invoke call will look something like this: 

client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody).setResponse(someOutput).invoke();

If you followed step 5.2, then your invoke call will look something like this: 

OutputClass myOutput = (OutputClass) client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, body).setResponse(someOutput.class).invoke();

If you followed step 5.3, then your invoke call will look something like this: 

byte[] response = (byte[]) client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, body).setResponse(byte[].class).invoke();

🚀 Ta-da ! You've called your first JellyFaaS Function 🚀

docs.title: Complete Code
docs.text:
Example

// creating a config object
Config config = new Config();
config.setApiKey("API-KEY");

// setting the client
Client client = new Client(config);

// setting the query parameters
Map<String, String> params = new HashMap<>();
params.put("queryParam", "foobar");

// setting an input object
SomeInputClass inputBody = new SomeInputClass();
someInput.setSomeAttribute("foobar");

// setting an output object
SomeOutputClass someOutput = new SomeOutputClass();

// a. invoking with an output instance
client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, inputBody).setResponse(someOutput).invoke();

// b. invoking with an output class
SomeOutputClass myOutput = (SomeOutputClass) client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, someInput).setResponse(SomeOutputClass.class).invoke();

// c. invoking with a byte[]
byte[] response = (byte[]) client.lookUp("shortname").setRequest(params, body).setResponse(byte[].class).invoke();

Next Steps

  • Create your first function
  • Get started with our cli tool
  • Get your API key

docs.title: JellyFaaS SDK Guide
docs.text:
This guide provides a general overview of the Python JellyFaaS SDK, including installation, best practices, and calling out to a JellyFaaS function.

For the complete Python JellyFaaS SDK class reference, see Python Class Reference. For more details of the general JellyFaaS API and SDK functionality, see SDK Introduction.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK simplifies interaction with the JellyFaaS API by providing a Client class to manage authentication and streamline requests. An API key is required to use the SDK. If you do not have one, refer to the Getting an API Key section.

API Credits

The functions used in this guide do not consume API credits.

docs.title: 1. Installation
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK is available on PyPI. To install, use the command appropriate for your operating system:

WindowsUnix/MacOS 
py -m pip install jellyfaas

python3 -m pip install jellyfaas

docs.title: 2.1 Creating a ClientConfig Object
docs.text:
First, create a ClientConfig object that stores your API key and manages authentication. The ClientConfig class optionally accepts a "debug" parameter, which enables debug logging within the SDK.

For most use cases, we recommend that you store your JellyFaaS API key as an environment variable, to reduce the risk of accidentally sharing it.

import os
from jellyfaas import ClientConfig

api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

if api_key is None:
    raise ValueError("API key is not set in environment variables")

config = ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)

docs.title: 2.2 Initializing the Client
docs.text:
Next, create a Client instance using the ClientConfig object:

from jellyfaas import Client

client = Client(config)

docs.title: 3.1 Function Lookup
docs.text:
To interact with a function, you must first look it up by its ID (short name):

client.lookup_function("helloworld")

This informs the Client instance of the function's request and response requirements, including method (GET, POST, etc.), query parameters, and body.

docs.title: 3.2 Setting the Request
docs.text:
The helloworld function requires two query parameters: firstname and lastname. You can set them as follows:

query_params = {
    "firstname": "John",
    "lastname": "Doe"
}

The request body for the helloworld function includes a message and a rating. You can define it as a dictionary or as a class instance:

DictionaryClass Instance 
request_body = {
    "message": "JellyFaaS is cool",
    "rating": 5.0
}

class Review:
  def __init__(message, rating):
    self.message = message
    self.rating = rating

request_body = Review("JellyFaaS is cool", 5.0)

With the query parameters and request body defined, you can set the request on the client:

client.set_request(query_params, request_body)

docs.title: 3.3 Invoking the Function
docs.text:
Finally, invoke the function:

client, result = client.invoke()
print(result)

docs.title: Function Chaining
docs.text:
All of the Client class's functions return the Client instance, enabling function chaining. The only exception to this is Client.invoke(), which returns a tuple of the client instance, and a response object. Using this functionality, the above example could be rewritten as: 

import os
import jellyfaas

api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

# Create client config instance
config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key)

# Create Client instance, lookup cloud function, set the request params/body, and invoke.
client, response = (
    jellyfaas.Client(config)
    .lookup_function("helloworld")
    .set_request(
        {"name": "arthur"}, 
        {"order": ["ham", "jam", "spam"]})
    .invoke()
    )

print(response)

docs.title: Response Handling
docs.text:
The SDK allows you to automatically map the response JSON to a specified class. This is useful for managing complex responses.

Request (input) and Response (output) class definitions for a given function can be found on the function's Marketplace page.

class MyResponse:
    def __init__(self):
        self.message = None
        self.status = None

client.set_response(MyResponse)
client, result = client.invoke()

print(result.message, result.status)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The JellyFaaS SDK provides custom exceptions for different error scenarios. Below is an example demonstrating how to handle these exceptions:

import os
import jellyfaas

api_key = os.getenv("JELLYFAAS_API_KEY")

try:
    config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key)
    client, result = (
        jellyfaas.Client(config)
        .lookup_function("helloworld")
        .set_request(query_params=query_params, request_body_instance=request_body)
        .invoke()
    )
    print(result)
except jellyfaas.AuthenticationFailedException as e:
    print(f"Authentication failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.FunctionLookupException as e:
    print(f"Function lookup failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.SetRequestException as e:
    print(f"Setting request failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.InvocationException as e:
    print(f"Function invocation failed: {e}")

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
Both ClientConfig and Client classes utilize Python's built-in logging module. Ensure that your application is configured to capture these logs:

import logging

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

Next Steps

  • Create your first function
  • Get started with our cli tool
  • Get your API key

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
Here is the complete example for invoking the helloworld function with query parameters and a request body:

import os
import logging
import jellyfaas

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG) # When enabled, JellyFaaS logs at the DEBUG level

api_key = os.getenv("<JELLYFAAS_API_KEY>")

query_params = {
    "firstname": "John",
    "lastname": "Doe"
}

request_body = {
    "message": "JellyFaaS is cool",
    "rating": 5.0
}

try:
    config = jellyfaas.ClientConfig(api_key=api_key, debug=True)
    client, result = (
        jellyfaas.Client(config)
        .lookup_function("helloworld")
        .set_request(query_params, request_body)
        .invoke()
    )
    print(result)

except jellyfaas.AuthenticationFailedException as e:
    print(f"Authentication failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.FunctionLookupException as e:
    print(f"Function lookup failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.SetRequestException as e:
    print(f"Setting request failed: {e}")
except jellyfaas.InvocationException as e:
    print(f"Function invocation failed: {e}")

docs.title: Python
docs.text: test
